Award.AwardTitle: Catalyzing New International Collaborations: 3D Morphometric and Biomechanical Analyses of the Human Lower Limb
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to initiate a new international collaboration between researchers at Pennsylvania State University and three European Universities - the University of Vienna, the University of Cambridge, and the University of Bologna. The goal of the project is to develop new methods for analyzing the three-dimensional (3D) structure and associated functions of human limb bones. The project will bring together experts in analyses of skeletal form and morphometrics from the Universities of Vienna and Bologna and experts in skeletal biomechanics from Penn State and the University of Cambridge. The primary goal is to develop new methods for integrative analyses of the bones of the lower limb in humans. These methods will be developed within the context of several specific questions relating to the morphology of the human lower limb and will be addressed using existing 3D high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) data and new HRCT data collected at Penn State and Vienna. The award will support planning visits, new data collection, and US graduate student training. The data produced will be of significant importance to a broad range of anthropological, paleontological, and archaeological studies.

Intellectual Merit. The expectations of this study are to develop a new understanding of the significance of variation in whole diaphysis cortical bone structure and whole bone shape. In so doing, this collaboration will illuminate the relative importance and usefulness of bone functional adaptation in shaping the elements of the human lower limb. The simultaneous analysis of bone shape and mechanical adaptation is expected to be a powerful tool to produce a broader understanding of skeletal functional adaptation.

Broader Impacts. This study enhances the infrastructure of research in physical anthropology by merging methodological approaches in morphological analysis to gain an understanding of skeletal variation and functional adaptation for use in paleontological and bioarchaeological behavioral reconstructions. This project will catalyze collaboration among researchers from the United States, Austria, Italy, and England, each of whom has specific expertise in 2D and 3D morphometric and biomechanical techniques. This project will enhance the educational experience of several U.S. students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels including one female minority graduate student at Penn State. Data, methods, and theoretical concepts will also be incorporated into current undergraduate courses taught by the PI at Penn State.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to initiate a new international collaboration between researchers in the United States, Italy, and the United Kingdom to develop new methods for examining the shape and function of the bones of the human lower leg. The intellectual merit of this project lies in combining to different analytical approaches to investigate the shape and structure of the human skeleton. Researchers with expertise in shape analysis and biomechanics were brouight together for a series of collaborative meetings and workshops to develop new approaches for analysis. New computed tomography scans were also taken so that large samples of human limb bones could be analyzed by the research team.

The results of the project reveal two important points. First, the relationship between the shape of human long bones and their biomechanical function is complex. Differences were found in the shape of the tibia (lower leg bone) in different human populations and when comparing humans to apes like chimpanzees, gorillas, and orangutans. The relationship between the biomechanical and shape data, however, was more complicated with fewer significant correlations between overall bone shape and indicators of biomechanical function.  

The second major revelation from the research side concerns shape variation in the lower leg bone (tibia) of humans and recently extinct fossil humans. The lower leg is an important part of the skeleton providing support and balance for the limb and upper body during walking. Differences in the human and ape tibia are readily apparent. Contrary to expectations, however, the tibia does not follow a simple pattern of change over the last 4-5 million years in fossil humans. The results of this analysis suggest that the knee joint becomes more human-like earlier in time than the ankle joint. The entire tibia looks more or less like what is seen in living humans around the time Homo erectus first departs Africa (~2 - 1.7 million years ago). These results provide very interesting insights into biological patterns of change and also provide insight into walking in living and extinct human species.  

Finally, one of the main goals of this project was to initiate a set of new international collaborations. The new international collaborative team at Penn State, Cambridge, and Ravenna will continue to pursue new research directions to better understand the shape and function of the human skeleton. 


Last Modified: 10/27/2014
Modified by: Timothy M Ryan

The lower leg is an important part of the skeleton providing support and balance for the limb and upper body during walking. Differences in the human and ape tibia are readily apparent.
